He is happy that, with this small loans process, he can expand his business. He hopes to have a big store in the next 3 years. He wants to continue his partnership with both AFSG and Kiva. He would like to thank Kiva lenders who help people in Afghanistan.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell such as baskets, shampoo, and Pepsi

loans.name: Debora S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35-year-old Debora Leonard. She is married and has three children ages two, seven, and thirteen. In 2005, Debora established her small grocery shack (or genge) business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about 30 USD every month from this business. Debora requires a loan in order to purchase more sugar, salt, cooking oil and home appliances in bulk. In the future, Debora plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is "genge." A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chiles, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and discover they are short an ingredient or two.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more sugar, salt, cooking oil and home appliances in bulk

loans.name: Barubina N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 41-year-old Barubina N.. She is married and has four children aged between ten and 21 years. In 2002, Barubina established her crops-selling business. She opens her business six days a week, five to eight hours a day. She is assisted by her husband. Barubina requires a loan in order to purchase more crops in bulk. In the future, Barubina plans to start another business. She thanks you for your support.

Naomi requires a loan in order to purchase more crops in bulk. In the future, Naomi plans to expand and establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Agness's Jerusalemu Group

texts.en:
Agness is married with 4 children ages 25, 24, 18, and 16. She also takes care of 2 other children aged 14 and 12 years old. She has been a vegetable seller since 2004. Every day, she works from 8am to 12pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Agness now hopes for a loan to buy more vegetables for resale. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Tasimbora.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for re-sale.

loans.name: Mary M.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Mary M.. She is married and has three children aged two, six, and nine. She also has two additional dependents that she cares for. In 2000, Mary established her genge (small shack selling groceries). Working seven days a week, and one to four hours a day, she earns about 90 USD every month from this business, in which she is assisted by her husband. Mary requires a loan in order to purchase more sugar, rice, soap, and cooking oil in bulk. In the future, Mary plans to expand and establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for an outdoor shop or stall is "genge." A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general grocery items such as onions, tomatoes, chiles, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and discover they are missing an ingredient.

loans.name: Apaikunda's Hekima Group

texts.en:
Apaikunda is 41 years old. She is married with 4 children ages 20, 17,16 and 10. She has been a maize, beans and milk seller since 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 2pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Apaikunda now hopes for a loan to buy more maize, beans, and milk for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Beatrice and Bertha, who have businesses dealing with shop ownership.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Thi Hoan

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Hoan, 39 years old, joined the TYM Fund in 2007. Her family relies mainly on agriculture and their income falls into the average range. Mrs. Hoan has 4 schooling children. Her first loan of 5,000,000VND (312.50USD) was used to invest in rearing pigs. She always took the time and money to purchase more bran and corn to feed the pigs, so after the first loan she sold the pigs and gained a profit of 8,000,000VND (about 500USD). She continued to use this profit to purchase pigs and pig feeds. Her husband is a construction worker with the monthly income of 2,000,000VND (about 125USD). This time, she would like to borrow 9,000,000VND (550USD) to continue investing in rearing pigs. Her average monthly income is 5,000,000VND (about 312.50USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thi Hoàn 39 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 2007, hoàn cảnh kinh tế gia đình chị bình thường vợ chồng chị làm nông nghiệp là chủ yếu. Chị có 4 người con đang ăn học, vòng vốn ban đầu chị vay 5.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn trong qúa trình chăn nuôi chị luôn đầu tư thời gian cũng như vốn mua cám, ngô làm thức ăn cho lợn, từ đó việc chăn nuôi của gia đình chị luôn đạt kết quả cao, sau một vòng vốn gia đình chị xuất chuồng và lãi được 8.000.000đ. Số lãi thu được chị lại đầu tư mua giống lợn và thức ăn chăn nuôi, Chồng chị là thợ xây nên công việc của anh cũng rất đều đăn thu nhâp bình quân 2.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 9.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư chăn nuôi. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.

loans.use: Rearing pigs

loans.name: Ikupa R.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Ikupa M.. She is married and has one child, aged nine months. In 2007, Ikupa established her clothes business. She opens her business six days a week and nine to twelve hours a day. Ikupa requires a loan in order to purchase more clothes in bulk. In the future, Ikupa plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially among the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Thi Truc

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Truc, 45 years old, has 5 children, 2 of whom are already married. Like many other rural families, her family relies mainly on agriculture. In 2003, she joined the TYM Fund and borrowed the first loan of 2.000.000VND (about 125USD) to invest in breeding ducks. Since then, her family's financial situation has improved and the quality of life has been better. Besides breeding ducks, she also used the subsequent loans to rear pigs. Currently, she has 7 pigs, 200 breeding ducks, each year yielding a high profit. Her children are all working and having stable monthly income of 3.000.000VND (about 187.50USD). This time round, she would like to borrow 8.000.000VND (500USD) to purchase fruit tree saplings and fertilizers. Her average monthly income is 5.000.000VND (about 312.50USD)

Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

Chị Nguyễn Thị Trúc 45 tuổi, cũng như bao gia đình khác ở vùng nông thôn nguồn thu nhâp chính của gia đình chị là từ nông nghiệp, chị có 5 người con đã có 2 con lập gia đình. Năm 2003 chị tham gia quỹ, vòng vốn ban đầu chị vay 2.000.000đ chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi vịt đẻ, việc gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi vịt nên luôn có thu nhập hàng kinh tế gia đình đã phát triển hơn, mọi sinh hoạt được cải thiện hơn so với trước. Kết quả từ việc chăn nuôi vịt kết hợp với việc vay vốn vòng sau gia đình chị lại tiệp tục đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn. Hiện tai gia đình chị đang nuôi 7 con lợn, 200 con vịt đẻ hàng năm thu nhập từ chăn nuôi của gia đình chị là rất cao. Chị có 3 con hiện đang sống cùng chị các con chị đã lớn và đều có thu nhập ổn định 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 8.000.000đ đầu tư mua giống và phân bón trồng cây ăn quả. Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng

loans.use: Buying saplings and fertilizers

loans.name: Happy S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is thirty-year-old Happy S.. She is married and has one child, aged fourteen. She also has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2002, Happy established her rice selling business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about 100 USD every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Happy requires a loan in order to purchase more rice in bulk. In the future, Happy plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Tham gia quỹ năm 1998, chị Hoàng Thị Hồng 37 tuổi điều kiện kinh tế trước khi trưa tham gia Quỹ ở mức trung bình, chồng chị làm nghề thợ xây nên ngoài làm ruộng ra anh còn đi làm thu nhập cũng ổn định 2.000.000đ/ tháng, chị có hai người con đang còn nhỏ đang trong độ tuổi ăn học. Trải qua 10 năm tham gia vay vốn chị luôn tích cực đầu tư vốn vào chăn nuôi nâng cao kinh tế gia đình. Vòng vốn đầu chị vay 500.000 đồng chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn, các vòng vốn tiếp theo chị vay cao hơn chị đã mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi và kiến thiết nhà cửa. Là người phụ nữ chịu thương chịu khó nên ngoài thời gian chăn nuôi ra chị còn đi cửu vạn, mỗi tháng thu nhập được 2.000.000 đồng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 12.000.000đ sửa sang chuồng trại và mua trâu.
Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoang Thi H., aged 37, joined TYM Fund in 1998. Before joining TYM, the financial situation of the family was not good. Her husband is farmer as well as a construction worker, earning 2.000.000 VND per month. They have two children, both of whom are still in school. For the past 10 years, Mrs. H. has been using all the loans to invest in breeding poultries. In the first round, Mrs. H. took out only 500.000 VND to raise pigs. After that, Mrs. H. has borrowed more loans to expand her business and renovate her house. As a very industrious woman, Mrs. H. is also a porter besides raising poultries at home, from which she earns about 2.000.000 VND per month. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 12.000.000 VND ($725) to renovate the breeding facilities and buy buffaloes. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Bupe I.

texts.en:

Working six days a week and 13 to 16 hours a day, she earns about 120 USD every month. She is assisted by her husband in the shop. Bupe requires a loan in order to expand and renovate her business. In the future, Bupe plans to open another business. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To expand and renovate her business

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Văn 32 tuổi, nghề nghiệp chính của gia đình chị là làm ruộng, ngoài ra gia đình chị còn làm nghề phụ đóng gạch táp lô bán. Chị tham gia Quỹ năm 1999 vòng vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 1.000.000đ chị đã đầu tư vào kinh doanh bán cát. Các vòng vốn sau được vay vốn lớn chị chuyển sang bán gạch táp lô. Với tình hình phát triển của xã hội nhu cầu về xây dựng của người dân đang cao nên công việc của gia đình chị rất phát triển. Mỗi tháng gia đình  chị thu nhập được 4.000.000 đồng. Ngoài công việc kinh doanh gạch táp lô gia đình chị vẫn đầu tư vôn vào chăn nuôi lợn. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ đầu tư mua vật liệu để làm gạch táp lô.
Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi V., aged 32, became a member of TYM Fund in 1999. Her family’s main source of income is from farming. But besides farming, they also pack bricks to sell. In the first round of loan, Mrs. V. asked for only 1.000.000 VND to buy and sell sands. But after that, Mrs. V. used the loans to buy and sell bricks. As the demand for building materials is enormous these days, Mrs. V.’s business has been very profitable. They make about 4.000.000 VND per month. In the next round of loan, Mrs. V. would like to borrow 10.000.000 VND ($625) to purchase materials to make bricks. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Bahati L.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Bahati K.. She is married and has two children aged 6 and 8. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2007, Bahati established her kuku (chicken) ranching business. She is open for business six days a week and five to eight hours a day. She is assisted by her husband. Bahati requires a loan in order to purchase more kuku (50). In the future, Bahati plans to expand and establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

Raising kuku is a popular micro-business in Tanzania, especially amongst SELFINA clients. (In fact, if you are a regular lender on kiva.org, you may be tired of reading about kuku.) For the rest of you... who or what are "kuku," you may ask. Kuku means chickens in Swahili, and raising them for sale is popular for a number of reasons: they require little start-up capital, require little space, and while they are growing they produce eggs, which can either be sold to provide a supplementary source of income, or eaten to provide a supplementary source of protein. There are hundreds of other reasons why raising kuku is so popular (maybe they are friendlier than other animals? Prettier?), but this is all time and space will allow.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Công 53 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ năm 1999. Qua gần 10 năm vay vốn kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển, vay vốn của Quỹ chủ yếu gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi, ban đầu gia đình chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Kết quả từ việc chăn nuôi lợn gia đình chị đã đầu tư thêm vào mô hình chăn nuôi bò sinh sản và bò phối giống. Viêc kinh doanh bò phối giống đã đem lại hiệu quả kinh tế cao cho gia đình chị, bà con quanh vùng trong địa phương đều lấy giống bò của gia đình chị, bò sinh sản đều đặn mỗi năm được xuất 1 lứa bò con. Kết quả từ việc chăn nuôi gia đình chị đã xây dựng gia đình cho 4 người con, và đều được chị xây cho mỗi người một dinh cơ khang trang. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 10.000.000đ tiếp tục đầu tư mua bò sinh sản.
Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi C., aged 53, joined TYM Fund in 1999. After 10 years of membership, her family’s financial situation has been enhanced a lot and keeps getting better and better. Mrs. C.’s purpose in asking for loans is usually to invest in breeding poultries. She used the loan of the first round to raise pigs; the profits she then used to raise cows. Raising cows has been very profitable for the family as people in her neighborhood and adjacent areas regularly buy them. Mrs. C. and her husband have four children, all of whom are married and live independently. In the next round of loan, Mrs. C. would like to borrow 10.000.000 VND ($625) to buy more cows. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Tutindaga N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 38-year-old Tunganege M.. She is married and has four children aged between two and 18. In 2003, Tunganege established her rice-selling business. She opens her business six days a week between nine and twelve hours each day. She is assisted by her children. Tunganege requires a loan in order to purchase more rice in bulk. In the future, Tunganege plans to establish another business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị N. 45 tuổi. Vợ chồng chị có 4 người con, 2 con có việc làm ổn định 2 con đang học đại học. Chị tham gia Quỹ năm 1999 vòng vốn ban đầu chị vay 1.000.000đ đầu tư buôn bán trứng vịt và chăn nuôi vịt, sau một vòng vốn vay đầu tư vào chăn nuôi gia đình chị nhân thấy rằng việc chăn nuôi vịt đẻ sẽ đem lại hiệu quả, các vòng vốn sau chị luôn vay vốn ở mức cao vẫn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi vịt và kết hợp mở lò ấp trứng. Hiện tai gia đình chị là nơi chuyên cung cấp vịt giống cho bà con quanh đia phương và các vùng lân cận và cung cấp trứng vịt lộn, bình quân môi tháng gia đình chị thu nhập từ lò ấp 4.000.000đ, 2 con chị đi làm thu nhập ổn định 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ mua trứng ấp.
Thu nhập bình quân. 7.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi N., aged 45, has 4 children, two of whom have already been working while the other two are in college. Mrs. N. has been a member of TYM Fund since 1999. In the first round, Mrs. N. borrowed 1.000.000 VND to buy and sell ducks’ eggs and raise ducks. After that, Mrs. N. realized that raising ducks and selling their eggs herself would be more profitable, so she has been investing all the loans of the next rounds to breed ducks for eggs. She is currently the supplier of ducks’ eggs for people in her neighborhood and adjacent areas. The business helps Mrs. N. earn about 4.000.000 VND per month. Her two grown-up children make about 3.000.000 VND per month. In the next round of loan, Mrs. N. would like to borrow 15.000.000 VND ($925) to buy more ducks. Her family’s monthly income is 7.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Devota S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Devota M.. She is married and has 4 children aged between 11 and 3. She has one dependent who lives with her because he is orphan. In 2002, Devota established her red palm oil business. Working six days a week, and 9 - 12 hours a day, she earns about US $330 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband.

Devota requires a loan in order to purchase more red palm oil in bulk. In the future, Devota plans to establish another business. She thanks you for your support. SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To purchase more red palm oil in bulk

loans.name: Cao Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Cao Thị Hà 54 tuổi, hiện tại kinh tế gia đình chị thuộc hộ khá trong địa phương. Chồng chị ngoài làm ruộng ra còn làm thêm nghề thợ xây bình quân mỗi tháng anh đi làm thu nhập 2.000.000đ. Chị có 3 người con, 2 con đã có việc làm, 1 con đang đi học. Ngay từ những ngày đầu Quỹ triển khai trên địa bàn chị đã mạnh dạn tham gia Quỹ vay vốn phát triển kinh tế. Vòng vốn ban đầu còn thấp nên chị chỉ được vay 500.000đ chị đã đầu tư chăn nuôi gà, vốn vay được tăng dần theo hàng năm, chị đã mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi chị nuôi thêm lợn, bò. Từ việc chăn nuôi có hiệu quả gia đình chị đã mua sắm được nhiều tiện nghi có giá trị trong gia đình. Các con chị đi làm hàng tháng thu nhập ổn định 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 11.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi. 
Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Cao Thi H., aged 54, has three children, two of whom are grown-ups and are working while the other one is still in school. Mrs. H.’s husband is not only a farmer but also a construction worker, earning about 2.000.000 VND per month. The family’s financial situation is relatively good compared to that of other families in her neighborhood. When TYM Fund opened its branch in her area, Mrs. H. didn’t hesitate to participate in the program and request loans. Because the loan of the first round was limited, Mrs. H. could only take out 500000 VND and used it to breed chickens. As the amount of loans that can be borrowed increases annually, Mrs. H. has used them to raise pigs and cows. The family’s situation has been improved a lot as a result, which allows the family to purchase necessary furniture for their house. Her two children who are working make 3.000.000 VND per month, which helps the whole family a lot. In the next round of loan, Mrs. H. would like to borrow 11.000.000 VND ($ 675) to keep investing in poultries. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND.


Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Maria S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 37-year-old Maria M.. She is married and has four children. She also has two dependents who live with her because they are disabled. In 2007, Maria established her retail shop. Working seven days a week, and 9 - 12 hours a day, she earns about US$ 100 every month from this business. She is assisted by her elder sister. Maria requires a loan in order to purchase home needs items. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop or stall is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To purchase basic staples for re-sale

loans.name: Thuy

texts.vi:
Chị Ngô Thi Thủy 41 tuổi, vất vả hơn các chị em khác trong địa phương, hạnh phúc gia đình đến với chị không lâu dài, khi xây dựng gia đình trong cuộc sông nảy sinh nhiều mâu thuận có nhiều vấn đề không hợp nhau nên vợ chồng chị đã phải chia tay, chị đã quyết định không đi bước nữa mà ở vậy nuôi con. Năm 1997 chị tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi,  ban đầu chị tập chung vào chăn nuôi lợn sau quá trình chăn nuôi lợn chị đã phát triển dần và mua được 1 con trâu phục vụ cho nông nghiệp. Tới đây chị muốn đầu tư vốn chăn nuôi lợn nái, con chị hiện đã lớn và đi làm thu nhâp 1.500.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn nái.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Ms. N. Thi Thuy is 41 years old. She had a harder life than most women, and her family's happiness was short-lived. She and her husband had encountered too many contradictions trying to build their lives together, so they parted ways. She decided not to remarry and stayed single taking care of her child. She joined the fund in 1997 and borrowed money to invest in raising pigs. After raising pigs she was able to make enough money and bought a water buffalo to use in her farming business. Now she wants to invest in raising sows. Her child is now grown and working, making average 93 USD per month. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 625 USD to invest in her sow raising business. Average monthly income 312 USD.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pigs

loans.name: Stenala S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Stenala E.. She is married and has one child, aged 3. She has one dependent who lives with her because he is an orphan. In 1993, Stenala established her banana-selling business. Working seven days a week, and one to four hours a day, she earns about US $10 every month from this business. Stenala requires a loan in order to buy more bananas in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more bananas in bulk

loans.name: Huong

texts.vi:
Chị Đặng Thị Hường 32 tuổi, ngày từ thời con gái chị đã được bố mẹ cho đi học nghề may để sau này đỡ vất vả, khi chị đi lấy chồng chị vẫn tiếp tục làm nghề may nhưng do thiếu vốn nên công việc may của chị không được đều đặn. Năm 2000 chị đã bàn bặc cùng với chồng tham gia Quỹ vay vốn để đầu tư vốn vào mua vải, có vốn chị đã mua sắm được nhiều vải kết hợp bản thân chị là người khéo tay có kinh nghiệm trong nghề nên công việc may của gia đình chị đã phát triển hơn, số khách hàng đến hiệu may của chị ngày càng đông. Chồng chị ngoài làm ruộng còn làm thêm nghề xây dựng bình quân thu nhập 2.000.000đ/ tháng kinh tế gia đình ổn định. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 7.000.000đ đầu tư mua vải.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Ms. D. Thi Huong is 32 years old. When she was younger, her parents let her go to sewing school so that she would not have a hard life. After getting married, she continued with her sewing business, but due to lack of money the income from her sewing business was not regular. In 2000 she joined the fund after discussing with her husband in order to borrow money to purchase fabrics. With the loan, she was able to buy a lot of fabrics, and combined with her experience, her business expanded bringing in more customers. In addition to rice farming, her husband also does carpentry/construction work, and makes average of 120 USD per month, which makes their family income more stable. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 425 USD to purchase fabrics. Average monthly income 305 USD

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Kiba A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 25-year-old Kiba M.. She is married and has two children aged 2 and 9. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2005, Kiba established her genge business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $40 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Kiba requires a loan in order to buy more home needs in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

Genge The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy more basic staples in bulk

loans.name: Yen

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Yến 38 tuổi, điều kiện kinh tế gia đình chị thuộc hộ khá ở địa phương, ngoài làm ruộng ra chị làm nghề hàng xáo và xay xát lúa gạo. Chị tham gia quỹ năm 2000 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 1.000.000đ chị đã đầu tư vốn vào làm nghề hàng xáo. Kết quả từ làm nghề cùng với vay vốn các vòng sau gia đình chị đã mua được máy xát gạo, thu mua lúa và xát gạo nhập cho đại lý. Ngoài viêc máy sát phục vụ cho việc buôn bán gạo của chi còn phục vụ sát thuê cho bà con địa phương, mỗi tháng thu nhập từ máy xát được 3.000.000 đồng. Thuận lợi cho gia đình có máy xát nên việc chăn nuôi của gia đình chị cũng rất phát triển, cám gạo rơi vãi đều được gia đình chị tận dụng vào việc chăn nuôi lợn. thu nhập từ chăn nuôi lợn của gia đình chị bình quân hàng năm là 30.000.000đ. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 15.000.000đ đầu tư vào mua thóc.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Ms. N. Thi Uyen is 38 years old. Her family's income is considered good for the area. In addition to rice farming, she also does rice-milling. She joined the fund in 2000; her first loan of 60 USD was invested in her rice-milling business. With the loan and income from her business, she was able to buy a rice-milling machine, and the rice seeds. In addition to her rice-milling & rice selling business, she also does rice-milling for hire for the local area. She makes average of 180 USD per month from her rice-milling business. Because of her rice-milling business, her pig farming business also expanded since she can use the bran from the rice milling machine to feed the pigs. Their income from the pig farming business averages 1850 USD per year. For this loan, her family wishes to borrow 925 USD to purchase rice seeds. Average monthly income 308 USD

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị L.  35 tuổi, chồng chị hiện đang đi xuất khẩu lao động tại mỹ, chị có 2 con hiện đang đi học. Chị tham gia Quỹ năm 2000 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 2.000.000 đ chị đầu tư vào may mặc, sau đó vừa may mặc vừa bán hàng tạp hóa. Các vòng vốn sau chị tiếp tục đầu tư vào hàng tạp hóa lãi xuất thu được chị đã quay vòng mở rộng kinh doanh. Bản thân chị là người phụ nữ khéo tay lại có vốn đầu tư mua nhiều sản phẩm vải để may quần, áo rất phong phú, khách hàng đến may tại cửa hàng chị chủ yếu là người dân  trong địa phương, thấy việc may mặc vẫn còn thời gian kinh doanh thêm nên đầu năm 2003 chị đã đầu tư thêm vốn mở một gian hàng tạp hóa. Hiện tại việc kinh doanh của gia đình chị phát triển cho thu nhập cao bình quân 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Chồng chị đi làm vẫn thường xuyên gủi tiền về phụ giúp gia đình. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị đầu tư 10.000.000đ mua hàng tạp hóa.
Thu nhập bìnhquân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi L., aged 35, became a member of TYM Fund in 2000. Her husband is currently working in the States under one labor export program. Mrs. L. only borrowed 2.000.000 VND in the first round of loan to invest in tailoring. As Mrs. L. is a skilled tailor, her shop is very popular in her area. Realizing that she still had time to do something else besides tailoring, Mrs. L. started using the loans from TYM Fund to open a small shop selling a variety of necessities at home in 2003. This has helped her family make about 3.000.000 VND per month. Her husband sends money back home every month to help the whole family. In the next round of loan, Mrs. L. would like to borrow 10.000.000 VND ($625) to purchase more goods for her shop. Her family’s monthly income is 5.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Quyen

texts.vi:
Chị Trương Thi Quyền 54 tuổi, kinh tế gia đình chị thuộc hộ khá tại địa phương vợ chồng chị có 6 người con, đã có 5 người con có việc làm và lập gia đình, 1con hiện đang học  lớp 12 và sống cùng vợ chồng chị. Chị tham gia Quỹ năm 1999 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 1.000.000đ  chị đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn. Các vòng vốn sau chị kết hợp đầu tư nuôi lợn và nuôi vịt, hàng tháng thu nhập từ chăn nuôi vịt là 3000.000đ. Kết quả từ việc chăn nuôi được chị đầu tư xây dựng gia đình và kiến thiết nhà cửa cho các con chị. Chồng chị mặc dù tuổi đã cao nhưng anh vẫn đi làm cho thu nhập hàng tháng 1.500.000đ. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và trâu.
Thu nhập binh quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Ms T. Thi Quyen is 54 years old. Her family's income is considered fair for the local area. She and her husband have 6 children, 5 are married with family and employed. 1 child is in the 12th grade and lives with her and her husband. She joined TYM fund in 1999. Her first loan was 60.00 USD which she invested in raising pigs. Later loans were used in raising pigs and ducks. They make about 187.00 USD per month from raising ducks. She was able to use profits from her animal farming business to take care of her family, and help build homes for her children. Her husband, even though up in age, is still working and makes 93.00 USD per month. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 625.00 USD to invest in raising pigs and water buffaloes. Her average monthly income is 312.50 USD

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Vaileth Y.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 28-year-old Vaileth K.. She is married and has three children aged 2,10, and 13. In 2004, Vaileth established her hair salon business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US$ 40 every month from this business. She is assisted by her husband. Vaileth requires a loan in order to buy more beauty supplies. In the future, Vaileth plans to undertake business renovation. She thanks you for your support.

Hair, hair and more hair! This is the place where you can buy long hair, short hair, curly hair, straight hair, red hair, blue hair, and then have it attached to your head, woven, cut, or plaited, and made to look like your own.

loans.use: To buy more beauty products

loans.name: Basir Khan

texts.en:
Basir Khan is 41 years old and lives in a household of 11. He is married and is an uneducated man. He has a retail shop, and he has been involved in this business for more than 15 years. He has good experience in his business. One of his brothers is working with Basir Khan. They support the family together. His brother is working part-time with Basir Khan.

Basir Khan wants to expand his business so he wants to take out an individual loan to enlarge his shop and further his business with more success.

He is happy with all members of his family. He wishes to open another shop in the next 2 years for his brother to run. He tries a lot and works very hard to do this. He would like to thank all lenders.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop

loans.name: Rehema R.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Rehema M.. She is married and has two children aged 8 and 12. She has one dependent who lives with her because he is an orphan. In 2005, Rehema established her genge business. Rehema requires a loan in order to buy additional stock of home needs items. She thanks you for your support.

Genge

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy additional basic staples for re-sale

loans.name: Chien

texts.vi:
Chị Võ Thị Chiên 35 tuổi kinh tế gia đình chị thuộc hộ khá trong địa phương, chồng chị đi xuất khẩu lao động tại Bỉ. Chị ở nhà vừa làm ruộng vừa làm nghề xay xát lúa gạo. Chị tham gia Quỹ năm 2000 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 2.000.000đ chị đầu tư vốn vào nghề hàng xáo, công việc buôn bán của chị phát triển dần dần chị đã tích lũy được sô tiền tiết kiệm kết hợp với vay vốn của Quỹ chị đã mua máy xát gạo phục vụ nghề hàng sáo của chị và làm dịch vụ xay xát tại địa phương. Thu nhập từ kinh doanh gạo và xay xát hàng tháng là 4.000.000đ. Vòng vốn này gia đình chị xin vay 10.000.000đ đầu tư vào mua thóc.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Ms. V. Thi Chien is 35 years old. Her family's income is considered fair in her local area. Her husband is a laborer in the town of Bi. She stays home to work in the rice field and also in rice milling. She joined TYM fund in 2000. Her first loan was 125.00 USD and she invested in rice milling. Her business expanded gradually. With her own savings and combined with a loan from the fund, she purchased a rice milling machine for her business as well as to start a commercial rice milling business in the local region. Income from her rice sales and rice milling business averages 250 USD per month. For this loan, she wishes to borrow 625.00 USD to invest in buying rice seeds. Her average income is 312.50 USD per month.

Translated from Vietnamese by Thu Ostrander, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Services

loans.name: Junes N.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 58 -year-old Junes M..  She is married and has seven children aged between 18 and 38. She has one dependent who lives with her because she is orphan. In 2006, Junes established her genge business. Working six days a week, and one to four hours a day, she earns about US $10 every month from this business. Junes requires a loan in order to buy soap, sugar, tomatoes, onions, groundnuts, and cooking oil. She thanks you for your support.  

Genge
The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal and don't have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy soap, sugar, tomatoes, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Edina A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 29-year-old Edina  M..  She is married and has two children aged 2 and 5. In 2005, Edina  established her fish-selling business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US$ 40 every month from this business. Edina  requires a loan in order to buy more fish in bulk. She thanks you for your support.  


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more fish in bulk for re-sale

loans.name: Mariam A.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 44-year-old Mariam  M..  She is married and has four children aged between 2 and 17. She has two other  dependents who live with her because they are orphans.  In 1998, Mariam  established her livestock-keeping business. Mariam  requires a loan in order to buy animal feed and drugs. She thanks you for your support.  


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy animal feed and drugs

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Hoàng Thị Hồng 33 tuổi, sống ở vùng nông thôn nên nghề nghiệp chính của gia đình chị là làm ruộng, những lúc nhàn rỗi chồng chị đi làm xây dựng bình quân 80.000đ/ ngày. Năm 2002 chị tham gia vào Quỹ vay vốn, vòng vốn đầu tiện chị vay 2.000.000đ chị đã đầu tư mua lợn giống và thức ăn chăn nuôi, qua 1 vòng vốn gia đình chị thấy rằng việc chăn nuôi có hiệu quả nên các vòng vốn sau chị đã vay mức vốn cao mở rộng mô hình chăn nuôi lợn và kết hợp nuôi gà. Hiện gia đình chị đang nuôi 8 con lợn và 300 con gà mỗi lần gia đình chị xuất ra thị trường cho thu nhập 30.000.000đ. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 8.000.000đ đầu tư mua trâu phục vu nông nghiêp.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng
texts.en:
Mrs. Hoang Thi H., aged 33, joined TYM Fund in 2002. As her family lives in the countryside, their main occupation is farming. Her husband is also a construction worker in his spare time, making 80000 VND per day. In the first round of loan, Mrs. H. borrowed 2.000.000 VND to buy pigs and food to raise them, which she realized is relatively profitable. Besides pigs, Mrs. H. also raises chickens. She now has 8 pigs and 300 chickens. She is able to make 3.000.000 VND by selling those poultries to the market each season. In the next round of loan, Mrs. H. would like to borrow 8.000.000 VND ($500) to buy buffalos for agricultural activities. Her family’s monthly income is 5.000.000 VND

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Vumilia S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 23-year-old Vumilia M.. She is married and has one child, aged 4. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2005, Vumilia established her used clothes business. Vumilia requires a loan in order to buy additional stock of clothes. She thanks you for your support.

Used clothing

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West's cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress, however the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To buy additional clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Mahkamtosh

texts.ru:
Mahkamtosh S. lives in the Vakhsh region. She is 47 years old, married and has 5 children. She has her own business. She brings cotton oil from Dushanbe and sells it in locally for a better price. She has been in this business for the past 15 years. She would like to obtain a loan to purchase goods. This will help her increase turnover and attract new clients. She plans to repay the loan within a 9 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Шарипова Махкамтош жительница Вахшского района. Возраст 47 лет , замужем и имеет пятерых детей . Занимается бизнесом . Привозит из города Душанбе хлопковое масло и продает у себя в районе по более выгодной цене. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 15 лет. Хочет получить кредит для того , чтобы закупить товар . Это поможет ей увеличить объем продаж и привлечь новых клиентов. Погасить кредит планирует в течение 9 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase goods

loans.name: Aisha S.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Aisha K..  She is married and has four children aged between 25 and 7. She has one other dependent, who lives with her because she is an orphan. In 1998, Aisha established her knitting business. Aisha requires a loan in order to renovate her business. She thanks you for your support.  


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment Ð a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To renovate her business

loans.name: Mahmadsaid

texts.ru:
Mahmadsaid G. lives in the Khourson region. He is 69 years old, is married and has 7 children. He provides for his family by raising cattle. He purchases and sells cattle. He would like to purchase another calf and for this purpose would like to obtain a loan. The loan will allow him to purchase another calf, raise it and sell at a better price. He plans to repay the loan within a 15 months period.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Гулямов Махмадсаид проживает в районе Хуросоне. Возраст 69 лет , женат и имеет семерых детей . Обеспечивает семью путем животноводства. Занимается купле продажей крупно-рогатого скота. Хочет купить еще одного бычка , а для этого ей необходимо получить кредит. Он купит еще одного бычка , откормит и перепродаст по более выгодной цене. Погашать кредит планирует в течение 15 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Phan Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phan Thị Tâm 54 tuổi, vợ chồng chị làm ruộng ngoài ra chăn nuôi trang trại cá, lúa và vịt. Chị có 3 người con đã có 2 con có việc làm còn một con đang học. Chị tham gia Quỹ năm 1999 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 2.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi cá và chồng lúa, các vòng sau chị đều vay vốn lớn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi vịt và mở rộng trang trại. Với mô hình chăn nuôi trang trại nên thu nhập của gia đình chị rất cao. Hiện tại gia đình đang có 8 sào ao thả cá và nuôi 300 vịt đẻ và 400 vịt thịt. Thu nhập từ vịt đẻ bình quân 300.000đ/ ngày, 2 con chị đã đi làm và có thu nhập 3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 10.000.000đ đầu tư vào mua thức ăn chăn nuôi.
Thu nhập bình quân. 6.000.000đ/ tháng.
texts.en:
Mrs. Phan Thi T., aged 54, has been a member of TYM Fund since 1999. Her family’s occupations are farming and raising poultries (chickens, ducks and fishes). She has three children, two of whom are working while the other is still in school. In the first round of loan, Mrs. T. took out 2.000.000 VND to raise fishes and plant rice. Mrs. T. then used the loans of the next rounds to raise ducks and expand her ranch. This has generated a lot of profits for the family. Mrs. T. currently has 8 ponds to raise fishes, 300 ducks for eggs and 400 ducks for meat. The profits from raising ducks for eggs are about 300000 VND per day. Her two children who are working have an income of 3.000.000 VND per month. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 10.000.000 VND ($625) to purchase food for poultries. Her family’s monthly income is 6.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Poultry

loans.name: Farida

texts.en: Farida B., 37, is a Tanzanian businesswoman. She is married with four children. Two of her children are twins. She has a clothing sales business. She sells traditional Tanzanian women's dresses (kanga and vitenge) at Mchikichini Matching Guys City Market in Dar-es-Salaam. She makes her purchases from Mnazi Mmoja Wholesale Shopping Center. The profit she generates is used to meet her family's daily needs and also to pay the school fees for three of her children. She requests a loan of $1200 to expand the business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Edina L.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45-year-old Edina S.. She is married and has four children aged between 13 and 27. In 2001, Edina established her red palm oil business. She opens her business six days a week and nine to twelve hours a day. Edina requires a loan in order to buy more red palm for extracting oil. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for S. client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more redpalm for extracting oil.

loans.name: Mavjuda

texts.ru:
Mavjuda M. lives in the Vakhsh region of Tajikistan. She is married and has five children. Hers is a large and very happy and friendly family. Mavjuda manages a store where she sells national holiday costumes for boys. She also has wedding dresses which she rents out. Mavjuda has been managing the store for the last 3 years and would like to purchase additional wedding dresses as well as accessories for them. For this purposes she is planning to take out this loan which she will pay back in 8 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Мирзоева Мавджуда проживает в районе Вахш. Работает в магазине , где продает торжественные наряды для мальчиков . Кроме того имеет свадебные платья , которые cдает на прокат. Занимается этим видом бизнеса уже 3 года. Необходимо завезти новые платья , а так же аксессуары для нарядов . Но для этого нужно сначала получить кредит . Погашать кредит она планирует в течение 8 месяцев. У нее очень большая и дружная семья. Она замужем и имеет пятерых детей.

loans.use: Expanding inventory to increase sales

loans.name: Ema E.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30-year-old Ema M.. She is married and has four children aged between two and twelve. In 2000, Ema established her boutique business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about 20 USD every month from this business. Ema requires a loan in order to buy more clothes in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy more clothes in bulk.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Lâm 35 tuổi, chồng chị làm nghề xây dựng công việc của anh rất ổn định cho thu nhập hàng tháng là 2.000.000đ, gia đình chị có vườn rộng nên chị đầu tư chồng các loại rau ngoài ra chị còn làm thêm nghề hàng xáo. Chị tham gia quỹ năm 2003 vốn vay ban đầu chị vay 1.000.000đ đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và làm vườn. Trải qua các năm vay vốn đầu tư vào chăn nuôi lợn và làm vườn nên kinh tế gia đình chị ngày càng phát triển. Chị đã sửa công trình phụ và chuồng trại chăn nuôi, mua sắm được nhiều tiện nghi trong gia đình. Hàng ngày chị đi chợ hàng sáo thu nhập bình quân mỗi ngày 50.000đ. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 12.000.000đ đầu tư mua lợn và bò.
Thu nhập bình quân. 5.000.000đ/ tháng
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyen Thi L., aged 35, joined TYM Fund in 2003. Her husband is a construction worker with a stable income of 2.000.000 VND per month. Mrs. L. makes use of the large garden behind her house to plant vegetables and fruits. In the first round of loan, Mrs. L. only borrowed 1.000.000 VND to invest in raising pigs and planting. After many rounds of loans, the family’s financial situation has been improved a lot. Mrs. L. was able to renovate the toilet facilities, the places for poultries and purchase necessary furniture. Mrs. L. makes about 50000 VND daily from going to the market. In the next round of loan, she would like to borrow 12.000.000 VND ($725) to buy pigs and cows. Her family’s monthly income is 5.000.000 VND.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa Nguyen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cattle

loans.name: Manka

texts.en: Manka A. is a Tanzanian businesswoman. She runs a business selling shoes and clothes in Kisiwan Street in Dar es Salaam. Her business is two years old. She purchases the items from KariaKoo Shopping Center and sells to customers in the small market of Buguruni Kisiwan. She sells both women's and men's shoes for children and adults . From the business, she derives income to feed her family. She requests a loan of $750 to expand her business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Kristina P.

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 32-year-old Kristina  M.. She is married and has three children aged six, nine and 12. In 2001, Kristina established her crops-selling business. Kristina requires a loan in order to buy more crops in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of microcredit in Tanzania. The organization is devoted to the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through microfinance as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; because of this, they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services. When a client needs working capital to buy a specific item, SELFINA buys the equipment for said client and extends a loan to her. The same equipment is then leased back to the client so they can use it while in process of paying back their loan, a process called a sale-and-leaseback arrangement. Once the loan has been repaid, SELFINA transfers the ownership of the equipment to the client. The advantage of microleasing over traditional microfinance loans is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy crops in bulk

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.ru:
Dilbar M. lives in the Djalollidini Rumi region of Tajikistan. She is 38 years old, married and has 4 children. Dilbar has been working in sales for the last six years. She manages a stand at the local market where she sells children's clothing. Due to recent slow down in sales Dilbar had spent some of the earning from the clothing stand on food for her family and now needs to take out a loan for 12 months to replenish her inventory for the upcoming school season.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Мирходжаева Дильбар проживает в районе Джалоллидини Руми. Возраст 38 лет,замужем и имеет четверых детей. Шесть лет как занимаетс яторговлей . Имеет торговую точку на рынке района. Продает детскую одежду. Оборотная сумма немного уменьшилась по причине , что торговля ослабла и вся прибыль ушла на питание. Поэтому она решила получить кроедит сроком на 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Expanding inventory

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema Issa is a 39-year-old Tanzanian married woman. She runs a business providing a food service to customers as a food vendor. Her business is at Buguruni Mnyamani in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. The business is three years old. Her family depends on this business income. She requests a loan of $ 550 to boost up the business.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Zebonisso

texts.ru:
Zebonisso S. lives in the Djallolidini Rumi region of Tajikistan. She is 30 years old, divorced and has 3 children. Zebonisso supports her family by herself, without any other help. She sells clothing at the "Barakat" market. Zebonisso wants to expand the assortment of goods she offers for sale and in turn increase goods turnover and for this purpose she has applied for this loan. Zebonisso is hoping to attract new customers to her stand by providing more clothing choices for sale. She is planning to pay back the loan in the next 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Султанова Зебонисо проживает в районе Джаллолидини Руми. Возраст 30 лет, разведена и имеет троих детей. Обеспечивает семью без чьей-либо помощи. Занимается торговлей на рынке «Баракат». Торгует одеждой. Хочет увеличить товарооборот и ассортимент товаров , путем получения кредита. Таким образом она сможет привлечь новых клиентов. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Increase goods turnover

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina baji is the wife of M. R. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. She has a two-room brick house and has been living in it for the last 12 years. Amina baji is a mother of six children: five sons and one daughter. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Amina baji’s husband has a food business. He runs a small hotel in his community and sells rice and chick peas. Amina baji is a housewife, and she also makes embroidered dresses to order. Amina baji successfully repaid her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (rice and chick peas) for her husband’s food business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy material (thread, cloth) for her embroidery business. Shamim baji and Razia baji each want a loan to buy thread to resell. Naseem baji wants a loan to buy a power loom machine.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for her husband's food business

loans.name: Soro

texts.ru:
Soro T. lives in the Djalollidini Rumi region of Tajikistan. She is married and has two children. Soro has a college degree in accounting and has been working in sales for the last 12 years. Currently she sells fish at the "Barakat" market and is planning to take out this loan to purchase a refrigerator. Soro needs the refrigerator to store the fish she sells, which will allow her to preserve it better and sell a quality product to her customers. Soro's business is the main source of income for her family. She is planning to pay back the loan in 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anya Lyuksyutova, Kiva volunteer

Темирбаева Соро жительница района Джалоллидини Руми. Замужем , имеет двоих детей. Имеет высшее образование , по специальности бухгалтер. 12 лет занимается торговлей . Продает рыбу на рынке « Баракат» .планирует получить кредит для покупки холодильника. Он ей нужен для хранения продуктов.Это даст ей возможность дольше хранить рыбу и продавать качественный товар. Ее бизнес –это основной источник дохода ее семьи. Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of a refrigerator

loans.name: Naziran's Group

texts.en:
Naziran baji is a wife of A. A. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. Kasur is famous for its sweetmeat and shoes. She has been living with her family in this city for the last 45 years. Naziran baji is a mother of two daughters. Her family has a decorative embroidery business. Naziran baji and her daughters make embroidered dresses, and her husband helps them by selling those dresses in a big market. She is out of stock now; because of that, she is losing her customers. She is applying for a loan to buy material (thread, cloth) to fulfill the orders of her customers.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Yasmeen baji and Naziran baji each want a loan to buy a power loom machine. Tasleem baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Khadija baji wants a loan to buy thread to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material to fulfill the orders

loans.name: Hanifa Nansubuga’S Group

texts.en:
Hanifa is a leader of a 5-member group. She is a 34-year-old woman who is divorced with 4 children. They are aged between 16 and 4 years. They are all in school. She rents a two-room house in which she lives with six people. There is piped water and electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area in the outskirts of Kampala.

Hanifa works seven days a week in Owino market in the center of Kampala. It's one of the biggest markets downtown where she rents a space to sell second-hand men’s trousers, a trade she has handled for over 2 years. She started with second-hand shoes. She buys them from wholesale shops and uses porters to carry the bales on their heads to Owino market. There is a market for her merchandise, and she serves both men and women wholesale and retail.

Her main challenge is the rainy season, which makes storage of her trousers difficult because the stores fill with water. This also complicates movement to and from her stall as the ground is always covered with mud, thus reducing profits in this season. There is a risk of buying a bale full of substandard clothes, which are rejected, thus lowering profits. She sometimes fails to get proceeds for the goods that she sells on credit, due to lack of integrity on the part of her clients.

After being with MCDT for 4 years and repaying 8 loans, Hanifa boasts of improved standards of living like providing her family with 3 meals a day and expanded business and income. Her major aspiration is seeing her business grow bigger so that she earns more profits.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Sruy

texts.en: This is the second time for Mrs. Sruy K. to take a loan to do her business activity. She and her husband, Mr. Phi Phall, are laborers in the village of Pouthi Reamea in Kandal Province. Aside from this business, Mrs. Sruy K. is a cow breeder. Since her second business is going well, she wants to expand it, so she decided to ask for a loan to buy two more cows which cost KHR 1,000,000 ($250) each for breeding. Mrs. Sruy K. has three children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while another one is attending junior high school. The youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy two more cows for breeding.

loans.name: Les Lingueres De Keur Salla Group

texts.fr:
In order to further the promotion of female entrepreneurship and the development of their community, the women of this group began businesses selling various products (foodstuffs, cosmetics, fruits and vegetables, etc.). They have benefited over the past two years from loans through the UIMCEC organization for the financing of their businesses. The loans have allowed each of these women to develop their commercial activity and to become financially independent.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

A fin de favoriser la promotion de l'entrprunariat féminin et le développement de leur localité,les femmes du groupe ont initié des activités de vente de divers produits (aliments,cosmetic,fruits ,légumes ...).Elles ont depuis deux (2) ans eu à bénéficier de prets au niveau de l' U- IMCEC pour le financement de leurs actvitées.Les prets obtenus ont à chacune de ces femmes de développer une activité commerciale et d' etre financierement autonome.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Safargul

texts.ru:
Safargul K. lives in Jalollidini Rumi. She is 47 years old. She is a single mother of 10 children. Her husband died 14 years ago. Since that time, she has worked in business. She opened a small bakery where she bakes flat bread and then sells it at the market. She plans to take out a loan to buy flour and other necessary ingredients for her business. This business is the sole source of income for her family. Therefore, she wants to expand it. She can pay off the loan in 3 months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa, Kiva Volunteer.

Курбонова Сафаргуль проживает в районе Джалоллидини Руми. Возраст 47 лет. Осталась одна с 10 детьми на руках. Муж умер 14 лет назад. С того момента она и начала делать бизнес. Открыла небольшую пекарню , где выпекает лепешки , а затем реализует на базаре. Планирует получить кредит для того , чтобы обеспечить дело мукой и другими необходимыми ингридиентами. Этот бизнес является единственным источником дохода ее семьи , поэтому она хочет развивать его еще шире. Погасить кредит сможет в течении 3 месяцев.

loans.use: Buying flour

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Mrs. Phan H. is a villager in Pouthi Reamea Village in Kandal Province. She is a pig breeder who raises four pigs. She now faces a small problem because she does not have enough money to purchase pig food to feed them. Thus, Mrs. Phan H. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. Her husband, Mr. Pring Chhorn, helps his wife in her business. Mrs. Phan H. is 39 years old and the mother of three children who are all attending school. Mrs. Phan H. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To purchase pig food to feed four pigs.

loans.name: Sugran M.ameen's Group

texts.en:
Sugran baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 25 years. She is the mother of four children: one daughter and three sons. Her elder son makes embroidered dresses. The next eldest to him has a lathe job. Her husband is a teacher and teaches the students about Islam (Muslim religion). Sugran baji is a hardworking lady, and she teaches her children to be hard workers. She is a housewife but she has a thread-making business. She buys sweaters and removes the threads from them. After washing it, she sells the thread in the market and earns a profit. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy material (thread, cloth) for her elder son who is in the decorative embroidery profession.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Khursheed baji wants a loan to buy a lathe machine. Nazia baji wants a loan to material (lentils, cooking oil, rice) for her grocery shop. Parveen baji and Naziran baji each want a loan to buy supplies (chair, mirror) for her beauty salon. Zareena M. wants a loan to buy material (thread, cloth) for her embroidery business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy material for embroidery business

loans.name: Srean

texts.en: Mrs. Srean T. lives in Preak Ta Ker Village in Kandal Province. She is a secondhand clothes seller. She is a 44-year-old widow with five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, while the others are attending high school. Mrs. Srean T. and her oldest daughter are breadwinners who can make a small income to support the family. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Srean T. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings to build a new house for her household.

loans.use: To build a new house

loans.name: Mariam Kakooza’S Group

texts.en:
Mariam has been operating this business for the last 4 years. She works six days a week and operates a salon and beauty shop. She buys her merchandise twice a week from the Kampala city centre and uses public transport back to her shop. Mariam rents the shop where she operates her business and sells on both a retail and wholesale basis. Her customers are women in her community and those on the move. She works on 3-4 customers daily. Her challenges include: high rental charges, transport costs, thieves who usually break into her shop, and flooding during the rainy season. The area where she is operating is prone to floods, and this destroys her merchandise.

She was inspired to join MCDT because it was dealing with the active poor. She caters to customers who were previously moving long distances looking for salons and cosmetics. She has been with MCDT for the last 3 years and is servicing her seventh loan. She has been able to improve her standards of living by getting three meals daily and also taking her children to good schools. Her main inspiration is owning a permanent commercial house where she will be operating and also seeing her business progressing.

Mariam is a leader of a 5-member group. She is 38 years old and married with 5 children. They are aged between 18 and 10 years, and they are all in school. Mariam owns a five-room house in which she lives with 7 people. She also takes care of two orphans of her late brother. There is no piped water, but she has electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area in the outskirts of Kampala.

loans.use: To invest in her inventory

loans.name: Doem

texts.en: Mr. Doem C. is a bread seller in Preak Pe Village in Kandal Province. Since his business is going well, he wants to expand it. He is requesting a loan to buy more buns to resell them. His wife, Mrs. Kuy Touch, assists her husband's business. Mr. Doem C. is 54 years old and the father of four children who are all attending junior high school. His wife is on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more buns to resell them

loans.name: Azizan's Group

texts.en:
Azizan baji is a wife of M. and lives in a small city named Kasur, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 30 years. Azizan baji is the mother of seven children: four sons and three daughters. Her husband makes cloth from his power loom machines and sells them in the market and earns a good profit. Azizan baji is a housewife and also sells thread to different areas. She owes a two-room brick house. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy oil to save their power looms machine from rust.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Tasleem baji, Bushra baji, and Hajira baji each want a loan to buy thread to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy oil for a machine

loans.name: Sruy

texts.en:
This is the second time for Mrs. Sruy I. to take a loan in order to improve her living conditions. She is a farmer who cultivates twice a year in the field which located in Pro Theat Village in Kandal Province. Although Mrs. Sruy I. tries to cultivate twice a year, she still has a little revenue, so she now wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Sruy I. decided to ask for a loan to buy a piece of land in order to cultivate rice and vegetables. Her husband, Mr. Yoen ThI., is a laborer who can make a small income to support his family.

Mrs. Sruy I. is 38 years old and the mother of five children. One of her children is employed in a garment factory while three more are attending school. The remaining one is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown in the picture because Mrs. Sruy I. is very busy with her work.

loans.use: To buy a piece of land in order to cultivate rice and vegetables

loans.name: Kutfiya

texts.ru:
Kutfiya H. lives in area Jalollidini Rumi. She is a widow with two children. Despite her difficult situation, being single with two children, Kutfiya began working. She works in business. She sells vegetables and fruit in a market. She has been doing this for two years. She plans to increase her sales by selling potatoes wholesale in the season when people are stockpiling them. If she sells her product wholesale, she can make good money and pay off her loan in 3 months.

Translated from Russian by Melissa, Kiva Volunteer.

Ходжабабаева Кутфия проживает в районе Джалоллидини Руми. Вдова и имеет дволих детей. Несмотря на тяжелое положение , оставшись с двумя ждетьми на руках , Кутфия вышла на работу. Занялась бизнесом. Торгует на продуктовом рынке , торгует овощами и фруктами. Занимается этим уже два года. Планирует увеличть товарооборот для того , чтобы завезти картофель оптом , как раз к сезону , когда люди делают запасы . Продав оптом продукт , она сможет хорошо заработать и в течении 3 месяцев расплатиться за кредит.

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: Beatrice Musisi‘S Group

texts.en:
Beatrice works five days a week and operates a salon. She buys her merchandise from Kampala city centre. She buys all types of goods from both retail and wholesale and uses public transport to transport her merchandise from Kampala to her salon/shop in Bwaise. She makes the trip twice a week. Her customers are women in her community and those on the move.

Her challenges include paying high taxes, high rental charges, and transport costs. Flooding is a problem during the rainy season as the area where she is operating is prone to floods, which destroys her merchandise. It was once a wetland. Another challenge is that of her business being seasonal. During periods when there is low demand for salons, she switches to selling cereals and legumes, mainly dried beans. She has been operating this business for the last 10 years and was inspired by the way women were moving long distances looking for salons. She has been able to improve her standards of living, provide her family with three meals daily. Her main inspiration is owning a permanent home to operate from and also seeing her business progressing.

Beatrice is the leader of a 4-member group. She is 28 years old and married with 2 children. They are 7 and 2 years old. The one aged seven years is in school. She rents a three-room house in which she lives with 5 people. There is no piped water and electricity. She resides and works in a semi-urban and slum area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala.

loans.use: To purchase more beans

loans.name: Oum

texts.en: This the second time for Mrs. Oum N. to ask for a loan in order to improve her standard of living. She sells lottery in Preak Thom Village in Kandal Province. She is a 44-year-old widow with three children. One of her children is a worker in a Chinese noodle restaurant, while anther one owns a small grocery store in the local village. The youngest one assists Mrs. Oum N. with her business. In order to improve her living conditions, Mrs. Oum N. wants to start a pig-breeding business. She decided to ask for a loan to buy ten piglets for breeding and reselling later at a better price.

loans.use: To buy ten piglets for breeding

loans.name: Les Lingueres De Falokh Group

texts.fr:
Through the loans obtained over the past two years from the UIMCEC organization, the women of this group are now shining examples. Each of them has organized her own retail business, where the residents of the area come to resupply themselves with basic need goods. With the income drawn from their businesses, they are able to pay for the medical and educational costs of their children and parents.
